title: Taane Milne
text:
Taane Milne (born 19 May 1995) is a <a href="Fiji%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Fiji</a> international <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who plays as a for the <a href="South%20Sydney%20Rabbitohs">South Sydney Rabbitohs</a> in the <a href="NRL">NRL</a>. 
He previously played for the <a href="St.%20George%20Illawarra%20Dragons">St. George Illawarra Dragons</a> and the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Warriors">New Zealand Warriors</a> in the <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">National Rugby League</a>, and was contracted to the <a href="Wests%20Tigers">Wests Tigers</a>. Milne also played for the <a href="Mount%20Pritchard%20Mounties">Mount Pritchard Mounties</a> and the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Warriors">New Zealand Warriors</a> in the <a href="Intrust%20Super%20Premiership">Intrust Super Premiership</a>.
Background.
Milne was born in <a href="Auckland">Auckland</a>, New Zealand. He is of <a href="M%C4%81ori%20people">Māori</a> and <a href="Fijians">Fijian</a> descent. He moved to Australia at a young age.
He played his junior rugby league for the <a href="Clovelly%20Crocodiles">Clovelly Crocodiles</a> and spent some time in <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> whilst attending <a href="Randwick%20Boys%20High%20School">Randwick Boys High School</a> and <a href="Newington%20College">Newington College</a> (2011–2013), where he played junior representative grades for Randwick as well as NSW & Australian Schoolboys teams alongside future Parramatta Eels backrower Tepai Moeroa. He was then signed by the <a href="Sydney%20Roosters">Sydney Roosters</a>.
Playing career.
Early career.
From 2013 to 2015, Milne played for the Sydney Roosters' <a href="National%20Youth%20Competition%20%28rugby%20league%29">NYC</a> team. On 18 October 2014, he played for the <a href="Junior%20Kiwis">Junior Kiwis</a> against the <a href="Junior%20Kangaroos">Junior Kangaroos</a>. He was again selected for the Junior Kiwis on 2 May 2015. Milne was released by the Roosters with "A questionable work ethic, including being late for training and poor training performance, coupled with some minor off-field dramas," said to be contributing factors.
On 27 October 2015, he signed a 2-year contract with the <a href="St.%20George%20Illawarra%20Dragons">St. George Illawarra Dragons</a> starting in 2016.
2016.
In round 8, Milne made his <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">NRL</a> debut for the Dragons against the <a href="Sydney%20Roosters">Sydney Roosters</a>. After further games in reserve grade, he returned to centre in first grade for 6 games at the end of season. Teammate <a href="Benji%20Marshall">Benji Marshall</a> said he, "has one of the best in and aways and flick passes I've seen at training. He is a very talented kid."
He was named in the <a href="New%20Zealand%20M%C4%81ori%20rugby%20league%20team">New Zealand Māori squad</a> for a match against the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Residents">New Zealand Residents</a> on 15 October 2016.
2017.
Milne played in 11 games in 2017, almost entirely from the bench. He scored his first try in round 11 against the Warriors, his sole match starting at centre for the season, and his only try for the year. On 6 May, Milne made his international debut for Fiji against <a href="Tonga%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Tonga</a> in the <a href="2017%20Pacific%20Rugby%20League%20Tests">2017 Pacific Cup</a>. Milne said, "I received a call from <a href="Mick%20Potter">Mick Potter</a> to play for Fiji against Samoa last year but I couldn't due to personal reasons, I was disappointed. But I had let him know that I was keen to play for Fiji this year. This has been an emotional moment for me. One of the best things being in camp is the devotion time and learning some Fijian songs. This has been one of the best camps I have ever been in."
In June, Milne signed a 2-year contract with the <a href="Wests%20Tigers">Wests Tigers</a> starting in 2018.
Selected for Fiji in the World Cup at the end of the season, Milne score 2 tries and 2 goals in the opening match against the <a href="United%20States%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">USA</a>. In his next game, he scored 2 tries and kicked 3 goals against <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Wales</a>.
2018.
Milne was sacked by the Wests Tigers in April 2018 after failing a drugs test. He joined the <a href="Mount%20Pritchard%20Mounties">Mount Pritchard Mounties</a> for the remainder of the 2018 season.
On 4 November, Milne signed a two-year deal with the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Warriors">New Zealand Warriors</a>. Milne had wrote a letter to coach <a href="Stephen%20Kearney">Stephen Kearney</a> asking him for a second chance to play in the NRL. Milne said "I told him I'm not a drug addict," Milne told the Telegraph. "I wrote to him – spelling errors and all – telling him that I wanted to play in the NRL again. That I owned up to my errors and I was on the right track. I knew I could offer something to the club".
2019.
In round 25 of the <a href="2019%20NRL%20season">2019 NRL season</a>, Milne made his return to first grade and made his <a href="New%20Zealand%20Warriors">New Zealand Warriors</a> debut against the <a href="Canberra%20Raiders">Canberra Raiders</a>.
2020.
On February 15, Milne suffered a badly broken nose in the pre-season <a href="NRL%20Nines">NRL Nines</a> tournament.
In March, Milne suffered a season ending knee injury whilst playing for the New Zealand <a href="Canterbury%20Cup%20NSW">Canterbury Cup NSW</a> team.
In October 2020, he signed a contract to join <a href="South%20Sydney%20Rabbitohs">South Sydney</a> for the <a href="2021%20NRL%20season">2021 NRL season</a>.
2021.
Milne made his club debut for South Sydney in round 10 of the <a href="2021%20NRL%20season">2021 NRL season</a> against the <a href="Cronulla-Sutherland%20Sharks">Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks</a>. In round 15, he scored his first try for Souths in a 46-0 victory over Brisbane.
In round 17, Milne scored a <a href="hat-trick">hat-trick</a> during South Sydney's 46-18 victory over <a href="North%20Queensland%20Cowboys">North Queensland</a>.
